questions.question:
Question 1: A 30-year-old patient is undergoing EEG with his eyes open. What is the expected frequency 
of the waves being recorded?
questions.explanation:
Beta waves are seen on the EEG of an adult recorded with eyes open. The frequency of these 
waves on an EEG is >13 Hz.

questions.question:
Question 2: A middle-aged obese man is being evaluated at the sleep clinic. During his EEG recording, he 
is awake with his eyes closed. Which of the following waves will be predominantly seen?

options.a: Predominant alpha waves with intermixed beta activity
options.b: Predominant beta waves with intermixed alpha activity
options.c: Predominant theta waves with intermixed delta activity
options.d: Predominant delta waves with intermixed theta activity

questions.explanation:
In a normal adult awake patient lying quietly with his eyes closed, alpha waves are predominantly 
seen intermixed with a variable generalized beta activity. This alpha rhythm is attenuated when the eyes are opened. 1075 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not a type of generalized epilepsy?
questions.explanation:
Jacksonian march is a feature seen in focal seizures, not generalized epilepsy. In Jacksonian march, the abnormal motor movements begin in a very restricted region such as 
the fingers and gradually progress to include a larger portion of the extremity. It represents the 
spread of the seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both upper limbs. 
They occur most frequently in the morning after awakening and are provoked by lack of 
sleep. This type of seizure is classified as  
. 1065 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). Myoclonic seizures are the 
predominant feature of JME and are now classified under both focal onset and generalized onset 
seizures. Generalized seizures arise at some point in the brain but immediately and rapidly engage 
neuronal networks in both cerebral hemispheres. Focal seizures arise from a neuronal network either discretely localized within one brain region or 
more broadly distributed but still within a cerebral hemisphere. Myoclonic seizures are characterized by: • Preserved consciousness • Preserved postural control • Lack of postictal confusion JME is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most 
commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated 
with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave 
pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate. 1076 
Sold by @itachibot 2017 ILAE-International League Against Epilepsy Classification:

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not seen in focal seizures?
questions.explanation:
The ictal cry is seen in generalized, tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). Jacksonian march, Todd's 
paralysis, and Epilepsia partialis continua are features of focal seizures. Jacksonian march is a feature seen in focal seizures wherein the abnormal motor movements 
begin in a very restricted region such as the fingers and gradually progress to include a larger 
portion of the extremity. It represents the spread of seizure activity over a progressively larger 
region of the motor cortex. Todd’s paralysis is a transient focal temporary paralysis usually persisting for a few minutes to 
hours (maximum up to 48 hours) in the postictal phase. Epilepsia partialis continua refer to continued focal seizures for hours or days. It is often 
refractory to medical therapy. Tonic contraction of the muscles of expiration and the larynx at the onset of a generalized 
tonic-clonic seizure will produce a loud moan or ictal cry.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the OPD with complaints of frequent fainting and sudden falls 
while playing. She sometimes falls off while sitting in the classroom hitting her head to the 
desk. She regains consciousness immediately and resumes her activity, and has normal 
behavior after such episodes. The girl is otherwise healthy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given history is most consistent with atonic seizures. Atonic seizures are characterized by a 
sudden loss of postural control and there is no postictal confusion. Options A and D: Absence seizures usually present as blank stares or unresponsiveness for a few 
seconds. Postural control is not lost during absence seizures. Option C: The girl regains consciousness immediately and has no associated complaints like 
sweating, fatigue, or tachycardia. She also resumes her activity after the episodes. Also, there is no 
precipitating factor that points towards syncope. Hence it is unlikely to be syncope. 1077 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the hospital. He is found to have a sudden brief lapse of 
consciousness with preserved postural control. No confusion is reported after regaining 
consciousness. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion 
is seen in absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern (as shown 
below). Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures. Option A: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control. Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking 
movement involving the entire body or a part of it. Option D: Generalised tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by post-ictal confusion.

questions.question:
Question 8: An unconscious patient with a history of seizures is brought to the ED. He then develops 
muscular flaccidity and excessive salivation. After a few minutes, he begins to regain 
consciousness and is in a confused state. This phenomenon is associated with which of the 
following types of seizures?
questions.explanation:
The scenario is suggestive of post-ictal confusion which is seen in generalized tonic-clonic 
seizures. It is not seen in absence seizures, atonic seizures or myoclonic seizures.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both 
upper limbs. They occur most frequently in the morning after awakening and are provoked by 
a lack of sleep. EEG demonstrates bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow- wave discharges. 
Which of the following features is not seen in this type of seizure?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myoclonic seizures. Post-ictal paralysis is not seen in 
these seizures. Myoclonic seizures are characterized by preserved consciousness (rarely very short loss of 
consciousness), preserved postural control, Lack of postictal confusion. 1078 
Sold by @itachibot Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the 
predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally 
synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges. JME or Janz's syndrome is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in 
adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME 
is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz 
polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.

questions.question:
Question 10: The following EEG is that of a 6-year-old girl who is easily distracted in class and exhibits 
poor scholastic performance. Seizures are precipitated by hyperventilation. What is the 
diagnosis ? 1067 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. This is seen in absence seizures. Absence seizures are characterized by a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved 
postural control that lasts only a few seconds. However, there is no post-ictal confusion. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and also the seizures. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the first-line agent for treating a patient with generalized tonic-clonic seizures?
questions.explanation:
The first-line agents in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) are Valproate, 
levetiracetam, and lamotrigine.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 16-year-old boy developed abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and 
gradually involved the entire arm. Following this, the patient experienced weakness and 
difficulty in moving the left arm for about an hour. Two similar episodes have also occurred 
in the past. Which of the following is the first-line drug for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are 
characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is 1079 
Sold by @itachibot carbamazepine.

questions.question:
Question 13: All of the following can be used as first-line agents in patients with typical absence seizures, 
except:
questions.explanation: Levetiracetam is not the first-line agent for the treatment of typical absence seizures. First-line drugs for: • Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, and lamotrigine • Atypical absence seizures: Valproate

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following is used as the first-line antiepileptic drug in the treatment of both 
generalized as well as focal seizures?
questions.explanation:
Lamotrigine is a first-line drug in the treatment of both generalized tonic-clonic and focal 
seizures.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is the drug of choice for a patient with generalized epilepsy syndrome 
having mixed seizures?
questions.explanation:
Valproate is the drug of choice in generalized epilepsy syndrome having mixed seizures. It is 
particularly effective in absence, myoclonic and atonic seizures. Valproate is usually first given alone (monotherapy) and if ineffective, another drug such as 
lamotrigine may be added. In generalized epilepsy, drugs such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine can increase 
the number of seizures. They can also provoke new seizure types - myoclonic or absence seizures. 
Hence, they are avoided. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures and is not used for GTCS.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with violent shaking of arms and 
legs for the past 1 hour. He is a chronic alcoholic whose last intake was 2 days ago. IV 
lorazepam and phenytoin are administered to this patient. After 5 minutes, the seizures have 1069 
Sold by @itachibot not stopped. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
With seizures occurring for 1 hour, this patient is suffering from status epilepticus. A second dose 
of lorazepam can be given to control this patient's seizures if there is no response after 5 minutes 
of administration of the first dose. Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired 
consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, it is defined as any one of the 
following: • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures. Management of status epilepticus: 1080 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 16-year-old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She 
has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological 
exam and intelligence. What would your advice be?

options.a: Stop the treatment and follow up
options.b: Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario of a girl on antiepileptics for 6 months with no further seizures, no 
family history, normal EEG, neurological examination, and intelligence, antiepileptics should be 
continued for another 18 months since she’s already taken for 6 months (minimum 2 years) to 
prevent seizure recurrence. Anti-epileptic drugs withdrawal is considered only when an adult patient has been seizure-free for 
2 years along with the following criteria: • Normal CNS examination including intelligence • Normal EEG and normal M˜I • Single seizure type • No family history of epilepsy. It is preferable to reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months. Other options: Option A: Sudden cessation of drug therapy may cause recurrence of seizure hence not advised. Option B: The patient has a seizure-free interval of only 6 months and therefore, is not yet eligible 
for considering medication withdrawal. Option D: Life-long treatment is not necessary in this case as the patient meets all the 
above-mentioned criteria for drug withdrawal after 2 years. Note: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), the most common idiopathic generalized epilepsy 
syndrome is known to have a high risk of seizure recurrence, and hence antiepileptics are 
continued lifelong in a majority of patients. 1081 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 30-year-old man on antiepileptic therapy for GTCS presents with weight gain, alopecia and 
thrombocytopenia. Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is the most likely cause for this 
presentation?
questions.explanation: Weight gain, alopecia, and thrombocytopenia are the side effects of valproate use. Adverse effects of Sodium Valproate (mnemonic: VALP˜OATE) • Vomiting • Alopecia • Liver toxicity • Pancreatitis • ˜ash • Obesity • Anorexia • Teratogenicity (most common: spina bifida), thrombocytopenia, tremors • Edema The first-line agents for treating GTCS are valproate, leviteracetam, and lamotrigine.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with West syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Café au lait is a neurocutaneous marker seen in neurofibromatosis, not a component of West 
syndrome. The triad of West syndrome is: • Infantile spasms (also called Salaam spells) • Developmental regression • Hypsarrhythmia (abnormal EEG) West syndrome is treated with: • ACTH injections • Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.question:
Question 20: A 4-month-old child was brought with repeated epileptic spasms. The child had reached his 
normal milestone at the age of 2 months. But the parents noticed that he lost the ability to 
hold his head steadily and he recently couldn't track light or sound. The EEG findings are 
shown below. What is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is of infantile spasms, developmental regression and the EEG showing 
hypsarrhythmia is suggestive of West syndrome. The drug of choice for this condition is ACTH. West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a 
triad of • Infantile spasm (also called salaam spells) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, 
symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities). • Developmental regression 1082 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypsarrhythmia (Himalayan wave pattern) on EEG: Characterized by a high-voltage, slow, 
chaotic background with multifocal spikes Treatment of West syndrome includes: • ACTH • Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following drugs is effective in controlling infantile spasms in a patient who has 
the neurocutaneous marker as shown in image? 1071 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a Shagreen patch, which is a typical feature of tuberous 
sclerosis. Vigabatrin is effective in the control of seizures in patients with tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in 
either the TSC1 or the TSC2 gene. The clinical features seen are as follows: • Seizures • Intellectual disability • Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas) • Shagreen patch • Hypomelanotic macules • Periungual fibromas • ˜enal angiomyolipomas • Cardiac rhabdomyomas. A Shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin-colored plaque, usually in 
the lumbosacral region.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 14-year-old boy develops an episode of involuntary jerky movements of the left hand 
accompanied by a repetitive chewing movement. He had a blank look on his face and was 
unresponsive during this episode. He also has no memory of the episode. EEG was normal 
and M˜I showed hippocampal sclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of focal seizure with impaired consciousness which along with 
hippocampal sclerosis is suggestive of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy. The following image shows left hippocampal sclerosis: 1083 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following statements is false regarding mesial temporal lobe epilepsy ?

options.a: It results in focal seizures with dyscognitive features
options.b: The person experiences an aura before the seizure
options.c: It is associated with a family history of epilepsy
options.d: Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine

questions.explanation:
Seizures of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy are not controlled with carbamazepine. The condition is 
refractory to anticonvulsant therapy but responds well to surgical intervention.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following drugs must be avoided in myoclonic seizures?
questions.explanation:
Oxcarbazepine is known to worsen myoclonic seizures and is therefore contraindicated in it. Drugs like carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine and phenytoin can worsen the myoclonic, absence, tonic 
and atonic seizures and are therefore avoided.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is seen in patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome?

options.c: EEG showing less than 3Hz Spike and wave discharge

questions.explanation:
EEG showing <3Hz spike and wave discharge is a characteristic feature of Lennox-Gastaut 
syndrome. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in childhood. It may 
occur due to various reasons such as developmental anomalies, mutations, trauma, infections, etc. 
It is characterized by a typical triad of • Multiple seizure types • Intellectual disability • Typical <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG Treatment includes administration of anti-epileptic drugs such as lamotrigine and sodium 
valproate. It is frequently refractory to medical therapy and usually has a poor prognosis. 1084 
Sold by @itachibot Note: EEG with symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern is seen in typical absence seizure.

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following is false regarding Lafora’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Glucocerebrosidase infusions are not the treatment for Lafora's disease. There is no approved 
treatment for Lafora body disease. The mainstay of management is anti-epileptic drugs, valproate in particular; however, other AEDs 
such as topiramate, ethosuximide, and phenobarbital can be used to control seizures. Most 
recently, perampanel, a new AMPA receptor antagonist AED, is shown to be effective. Lafora body disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease and has an adolescent 
onset. It is associated with polyglucosan intracellular inclusion bodies. It is characterized by: • Progressive myoclonus • Epileptic seizures • Dementia • Ataxia. Diagnosis is by DNA sequencing. Death usually occurs within 10 years of the onset of the disease.

questions.question:
Question 27: You are at a criminal court to provide medical testimony. The trial ends with the accused 
being sentenced to life imprisonment. Abruptly, the convict breaks into uncontrollable 
laughter. Within minutes, he collapses and starts to have a seizure. His lawyer reports that he 
has a childhood seizure disorder. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of a gelastic seizure. This condition is also known as gelastic epilepsy, and is a rare type of seizure that involves a 
sudden burst of energy, usually in the form of laughing or crying. It is seen when the seizure focus 
is within the left prefrontal cortex. Gelastic seizures have been associated classically with 
hypothalamic hamartomas. Option A: Kluver Bucy syndrome is characterized by hypersexuality, placidity, a tendency to 
explore the environment with the mouth, inability to recognize the emotional significance of 
visual stimuli, and constantly shifting attention, called hypermetamorphosis. Option B: Witzelsucht is a tendency to joke and make puns. Option C: Pseudobulbar affect is defined by involuntary, sudden, and frequent episodes of 
laughing or crying that are generally out of proportion or inappropriate to the situation.

questions.question:
Question 28: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the OPD following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She had 
previous episodes of sudden falls at school and also sometimes stares with a blank face. She is 
also found to be having poor scholastic performance. Her EEG reveals a slow spike and wave 
pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario reveals multiple types of seizures such as atonic seizures (sudden falls), 
absence seizures (blank stares and unresponsive), and generalized tonic-clonic seizures in this 
patient. This is a characteristic feature of Lenox-Gastaut syndrome. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in childhood. It may 
occur due to various reasons such as developmental anomalies, mutations, trauma, infections, etc. 1085 
Sold by @itachibot It is characterized by a typical triad of • Multiple seizure types • Intellectual disability • Typical <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG Treatment includes administration of anti-epileptic drugs such as lamotrigine and sodium 
valproate. It is frequently refractory to medical therapy and usually has a poor prognosis. 1086 
Sold by @itachibot Ischemic Stroke
